question: Mention and briefly explain the characteristics of a data collection called Big Data
ground_truth: Big Data refers to a large and complex data set that has certain characteristics, often referred to as the “5Vs”. These characteristics are Volume, Velocity, Variety, Veracity, and Value. 1. Volume: Big Data is characterized by its very large size, which can reach petabytes or even exabytes. Examples include data from social media, IoT sensors, online transactions, and others. 2. Velocity: Big Data is generated at a high speed and needs to be processed in real-time or near real-time. Streaming data from social media, online transaction logs, and sensor data are examples where data needs to be analyzed in real-time or near real-time. 3. Variety: Big Data comes in various types and formats, ranging from structured data (such as databases), semi-structured (such as XML, JSON), to unstructured data (such as text, video, and images). This variety adds complexity to data management and analysis. 4. Veracity: Big Data often contains uncertainty, incompleteness, or even errors due to the large volume and variety of data sources. Managing veracity means ensuring the data analyzed is high quality and trustworthy. 5. Value: Big Data has the potential to provide valuable insights and drive strategic decision making. It can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, supply chain optimization, and more effective and personalized treatment planning.
answer: The term "Big Data" refers to large amounts of data that are complex and difficult to process using traditional methods.

question: Mention and briefly explain the characteristics of a data collection called Big Data
ground_truth: Big Data refers to a large and complex data set that has certain characteristics, often referred to as the “5Vs”. These characteristics are Volume, Velocity, Variety, Veracity, and Value. 1. Volume: Big Data is characterized by its very large size, which can reach petabytes or even exabytes. Examples include data from social media, IoT sensors, online transactions, and others. 2. Velocity: Big Data is generated at a high speed and needs to be processed in real-time or near real-time. Streaming data from social media, online transaction logs, and sensor data are examples where data needs to be analyzed in real-time or near real-time. 3. Variety: Big Data comes in various types and formats, ranging from structured data (such as databases), semi-structured (such as XML, JSON), to unstructured data (such as text, video, and images). This variety adds complexity to data management and analysis. 4. Veracity: Big Data often contains uncertainty, incompleteness, or even errors due to the large volume and variety of data sources. Managing veracity means ensuring the data analyzed is high quality and trustworthy. 5. Value: Big Data has the potential to provide valuable insights and drive strategic decision making. It can assist in disease diagnosis, drug development, supply chain optimization, and more effective and personalized treatment planning.
answer: The definition of big data is as follows: a. Variety - Big data has characteristics that are diverse and not homogeneous, can be structured or unstructured, and come from various sources. b. Velocity - This refers to the speed at which data is created in real-time, changes rapidly, and has characteristics that change quickly from the variable or data type side. c. Volume - Big data represents a large volume of data generated from various sources. d. Veracity - Big data has a strong relationship with accuracy and validity, requiring deep analysis. e. Value - Big data has high value when processed correctly and used effectively. Reference: Prayogo, C., 2019, What is Big Data? <https://www.wartaekonomi.co.id/read/261904/apa-itu-big-data>, accessed on May 7, 2021.
